content.description:
Overhung rock tower with rock horn finish. Sparse start leads to easier, but pumpy, sidepulls and slopers to an arête finishing crux.

 Belay spot is sloping dirt. There's a handy tree for the belayer that also could be in the fall line for a climber on top rope. You could also maybe pendulum into the wall on the left, but my biggest challenge was getting back to the wall.
content.protection: 7 bolts. Chains. There's a bolt for getting to the anchors for toproping.
content.location: Far left of Section 3 to the right of the big, dark, offwidth. Anchors at the top of the left of two rock horns.

content.description: Fun, relatively steep climb on jugs. Can be made easier by climbing to the right of the bolt line or harder by staying on the arete to the left.
content.location: On the right side of Section 3, just left of the moss filled gully.

content.description:
This route climbs the eye-catching rock horn with a distinctly overhanging finish.

 Ascend mediocre but easy climbing following a funky crack to a stance just before the clean face. The gear here is questionable but the climbing is pretty easy (offset cams/nuts would probably work best). Once at the overlap, a good small cam can be placed to protect the moves up to the first bolt.

 Once clipped, work your way up the pumpy face to a decent stance before tackling the unique horn finish.
content.protection: Small nuts and cams. Offsets would be useful.
content.location: Overhanging rock horn. Can't miss it.

content.description: A really fun route that starts off pumpy and ends on a technical slab.This route is another "Unknown name" which is annoying, so I renamed it. I know that's bad style, but hopefully it will help keep track of the routes better.
content.protection: 5 bolts to new anchors re bolted 2019
content.location: This is the second route to the left of the gully that separates sections 2 and 3. The gully is 5.6, then a 5.8 sport route, then this route. the route to the left of this is a 10d.

content.description:
A fun easy trad lead up a corner gully. Start in between 2 bolted routes and head up and left. You can clip 1-2 bolts from the route to the left if needed. You can stem in the start and then climb a few slabby face moves with crack pockets for pro (thin pro and slightly run out) then throw a cam in a horizontal towards the top into a nice handjam and up to the anchors.

 I spent a lot of time cleaning this route, it looked like it had never been climbed before. I knocked down a ton of loose rocks and brushed off a lot of moss. It still needs some more work, but its good to go now.
content.protection: Standard single rack. Nuts, small cams and #2 and #3 to a new anchor re bolted in 2019.

content.description: The book says this is a 5.11a but it’s 5.10a. This is a pretty fun route with some crack moves and side pulls and knobs. Not as pumpy as the routes to the right but enough to make you need to shake out mid route.
content.protection: 5 bolts to rap rings. This route would be hard to TR, but you could lead the 5.10 to the right or the 5.8 next to the gully crack and swing over.
content.location: This route starts just before heading up the trail to the back wall. It is just to the right of the rock horn route.

content.description: Steep start on jugs leads to small crimps and the crux. Then head up right to the shared anchor with the climb to the right (Pump up the Slab). Be mindful of fall potential between the 2nd and 3rd bolts.
content.location: Start at the middle and steepest part of Section 3.

content.description: Shady left-half of the crag. (OK, the whole thing is shady.)
